title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Mauritania between May 2020 and December 2020
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Mauritania signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020). Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between May 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $15,051,803,62. At the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Mauritania. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Mauritania between May 2020 and December 2020

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Mauritania signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020). Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between May 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $15,051,803,62. At the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt service suspension agreement is a financial arrangement without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt suspension agreement, financial terms, no specific project or environmental focus mentioned

title: Chinese Embassy donated teaching equipment to three Chinese schools in Mauritius (linked to #85665, #85668)
description: On October 31, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Mauritius held a donation ceremony in which they donated teaching equipment to three Chinese schools in Mauritius (Xinhua School, Guangming Chinese School and Huaxia Chinese School). The ceremony was held at the Heen Foh Hall in Port Louis, Mauritius. In attendance were Sun Gongyi, the Chinese Ambassador, and Aneeta Ghoorah, Director of Primary Education for the Mauritus Ministry of Education, both of whom gave speeches at the event. Also in attendance were representatives of the Chinese community in Mauritius.   The donation consisted of Chinese language teaching materials, projectors, and other unspecified educational materials, which in photographs of the event appeared to include textbooks and storybooks.   The Chinese embassy has made similar donations in the past, including the donation of Chinese tutoring equipment and instruments to three Chinese Schools in 2018 (ID #85668).
staff_comments: In Chinese, the donation is referred to as the 向华文学校捐赠教材和教学设备仪式。
combined_text:

# Description
On October 31, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Mauritius held a donation ceremony in which they donated teaching equipment to three Chinese schools in Mauritius (Xinhua School, Guangming Chinese School and Huaxia Chinese School). The ceremony was held at the Heen Foh Hall in Port Louis, Mauritius. In attendance were Sun Gongyi, the Chinese Ambassador, and Aneeta Ghoorah, Director of Primary Education for the Mauritus Ministry of Education, both of whom gave speeches at the event. Also in attendance were representatives of the Chinese community in Mauritius.   The donation consisted of Chinese language teaching materials, projectors, and other unspecified educational materials, which in photographs of the event appeared to include textbooks and storybooks.   The Chinese embassy has made similar donations in the past, including the donation of Chinese tutoring equipment and instruments to three Chinese Schools in 2018 (ID #85668).
justification: Project focuses on educational support without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of teaching equipment and materials to schools, educational focus

title: China donates first batch of COVID medical supplies to Mauritius
description: On April 18, 2020, a first batch of anti-epidemic supplies donated by the Chinese government arrived in Mauritius on a chartered plane. The supplies included face masks, personal protective equipment, testing kits, and thermometers, according to CGTN Africa.    Further according to CGTN, this delivery was the first of several batches of COVID supplies that were to arrive in Mauritius.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates first batch of COVID medical supplies to Mauritius

# Description
On April 18, 2020, a first batch of anti-epidemic supplies donated by the Chinese government arrived in Mauritius on a chartered plane. The supplies included face masks, personal protective equipment, testing kits, and thermometers, according to CGTN Africa.    Further according to CGTN, this delivery was the first of several batches of COVID supplies that were to arrive in Mauritius.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical supplies including face masks, PPE, testing kits, and thermometers

title: Chinese government donates more pandemic medical supplies to Mauritius Ministry of Health
description: On July 31, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Mauritius and the Ministry of Health and Wellness of Mauritius jointly held a handover ceremony for the donation of epidemic prevention materials from China to Mauritius. Chinese Ambassador Sun Gongyi, and the Minister of Health and Wellness of Mauritius, Kailesh Jagutpal, attended the handover ceremony. The exact supplies donated were unspecified. Previous COVID supplies donations have included masks, testing kits, and thermometers.   This donation was one batch in a series of COVID supplies donations from China-  previous batches are captured in #92229 and #92238.
combined_text:
# Sector

On July 31, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Mauritius and the Ministry of Health and Wellness of Mauritius jointly held a handover ceremony for the donation of epidemic prevention materials from China to Mauritius. Chinese Ambassador Sun Gongyi, and the Minister of Health and Wellness of Mauritius, Kailesh Jagutpal, attended the handover ceremony. The exact supplies donated were unspecified. Previous COVID supplies donations have included masks, testing kits, and thermometers. justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for pandemic response, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Donation of unspecified epidemic prevention materials, focus on healthcare support

title: Chinese SOEs donate oil cleanup supplies to Mauritius after oil spill (linked to #92242)
description: On July 25, 2020, a 200,000-ton Japanese freighter Wakashio ran aground near the Blue Bay Marine Park in Mauritius while on its way from China to Brazil. On August 6, 2020, the ship suffered a serious oil spill. About 1,000 tons of heavy oil leaked and polluted the nearby sea and beaches. The Mauritian government declared a state of environmental emergency on August 7th.  In response to the disaster, 15 Chinese companies, the majority of which were state owned enterprises (SOEs), donated pollution clean up supplies such as geotextiles, safety nets,  protective clothing, large iron buckets, and drones. It is unclear which company donated which supplies, and in what quantity. The total worth of the donation was about 1.37 million rupees by August 12, 2020, and was given to the Ministry of Environmental Protection of Mauritius.   The companies that participated in this donation included China State Construction Engineering, Beijing Construction Engineering, China Road and Bridge, Huawei, Sinohydro, China Jiangsu International, Tianli Spinning, Shanxi Jinfei co., China International Water & Electrical Corp, Henan Water Conservancy Investment Group, Kuanfu Tea, Yihai Properties Group, and Yutu. The full list of enterprises is unavailable. This effort was organized under the leadership of the Party Committee of the Chinese Embassy in Mauritius and the Chinese-Funded Enterprise Association in Mauritius. The companies also organized 200 employees to volunteer as part of beach cleanup activities.   The donation of Shanxi Construction is captured in project #92242.
staff_comments: 1) Transaction amount not recorded since it is unknown how much of the donation came from state-owned companies compared to private sector companies.  The total amount provided in the description is taken from the website of the Chinese Ministry of Commerce. 2) It is unclear what supplies were donated on what date and by which company. 3) Commitment date and implementation dates are estimated based on the beginning of the oil leak (Aug. 6) and the date given by MofCom of the final total of donations (Aug. 12).
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese SOEs donate oil cleanup supplies to Mauritius after oil spill (linked to #92242)

# Description
On July 25, 2020, a 200,000-ton Japanese freighter Wakashio ran aground near the Blue Bay Marine Park in Mauritius while on its way from China to Brazil. On August 6, 2020, the ship suffered a serious oil spill. About 1,000 tons of heavy oil leaked and polluted the nearby sea and beaches. The Mauritian government declared a state of environmental emergency on August 7th.  In response to the disaster, 15 Chinese companies, the majority of which were state owned enterprises (SOEs), donated pollution clean up supplies such as geotextiles, safety nets,  protective clothing, large iron buckets, and drones. It is unclear which company donated which supplies, and in what quantity. The total worth of the donation was about 1.37 million rupees by August 12, 2020, and was given to the Ministry of Environmental Protection of Mauritius.   The companies that participated in this donation included China State Construction Engineering, Beijing Construction Engineering, China Road and Bridge, Huawei, Sinohydro, China Jiangsu International, Tianli Spinning, Shanxi Jinfei co., China International Water & Electrical Corp, Henan Water Conservancy Investment Group, Kuanfu Tea, Yihai Properties Group, and Yutu. The full list of enterprises is unavailable. This effort was organized under the leadership of the Party Committee of the Chinese Embassy in Mauritius and the Chinese-Funded Enterprise Association in Mauritius. The companies also organized 200 employees to volunteer as part of beach cleanup activities.   The donation of Shanxi Construction is captured in project #92242.
justification: Project involves emergency response and cleanup efforts following an environmental disaster, with no direct energy or infrastructure development focus
evidence: Donation of cleanup supplies, volunteer beach cleanup activities, organized by Chinese SOEs in response to oil spill emergency

title: China's Shanxi Investment Construction Engineering Group donates disaster relief materials to Mauritius (Linked to Project ID #92240)
description: In August of 2020, Shanxi Investment Construction Engineering Group donated disaster relief materials to Mauritius following a large oil spill that took place near Blue Bay Marine Park. The oil spill took place after the Japanese freighter Wakashio ran aground near the Blue Bay Marine Park while on its way to Brazil. This crash took place on July 25, 2020.  On August 6th, oil began to leak from the ship. As of August 19, 2020, about 1,000 tons of heavy oil had leaked and polluted the nearby sea and beaches. The Mauritian government declared a state of environmental emergency.  The supplies donated by Shanxi Investment Construction Engineering Group included 200 pairs of rubber shoes, 200 pairs of rubber gloves, 300 bottles of mineral water and other relief materials. The materials were shipped to various designated locations where the company’s project staff and locals worked to make oil separators, put sugarcane leaves and plastic bottles on geotextiles, and place them in the sea to prevent the spread of oil. The donation was part of a larger effort by Chinese state enterprises to assist in the oil spill cleanup (captured in project #92240).
staff_comments: 1) Commitment date is estimated based on the beginning of the oil leak (Aug. 6).
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China's Shanxi Investment Construction Engineering Group donates disaster relief materials to Mauritius (Linked to Project ID #92240)

# Description
In August of 2020, Shanxi Investment Construction Engineering Group donated disaster relief materials to Mauritius following a large oil spill that took place near Blue Bay Marine Park. The oil spill took place after the Japanese freighter Wakashio ran aground near the Blue Bay Marine Park while on its way to Brazil. This crash took place on July 25, 2020.  On August 6th, oil began to leak from the ship. As of August 19, 2020, about 1,000 tons of heavy oil had leaked and polluted the nearby sea and beaches. The Mauritian government declared a state of environmental emergency.  The supplies donated by Shanxi Investment Construction Engineering Group included 200 pairs of rubber shoes, 200 pairs of rubber gloves, 300 bottles of mineral water and other relief materials. The materials were shipped to various designated locations where the company’s project staff and locals worked to make oil separators, put sugarcane leaves and plastic bottles on geotextiles, and place them in the sea to prevent the spread of oil. The donation was part of a larger effort by Chinese state enterprises to assist in the oil spill cleanup (captured in project #92240).
justification: Project involves disaster relief and environmental cleanup assistance without direct energy or infrastructure development focus
evidence: Donation of relief materials, oil spill cleanup assistance, no energy-related components

title: [China Co-Financing Fund] IDB Invest administers $4.6 million loan from CHC for Xoxocotla Solar PV Plant
description: In January 2020, IDB Invest, a member of the Inter-American Development Bank Group (IDB), provided a financing package of $17.2 million in loans to X-Elio for the construction and maintenance of the Xoxocotla solar photovoltaic plant. The financing package included a 4.6 million USD loan from the China Co-Financing Fund for Latin America and the Caribbean, as well as USD 9.3 million of IDB Invest's own funds and USD 3.3 million of blended financing from the Canadian Climate Fund (C2F).  The Xoxocotla PV plant will be located in the municipality of Ayala, in the state of Morelos, and will have a 70MWAC capacity. It is hoped to displace the equivalent of 1.6 million tons of carbon dioxide over the next 20 years and is part of the Government of Mexico's goal of increasing the percentage of the country's electricity generated through clean energy.   X-Elio was awarded a long-term Power Purchase Agreement (“PPA”) for the plant by the Mexican Federal Electricity Agency, Centro Nacional de Control de Energía (“CENACE”) in September 2016. Under this agreement, X-Elio will sell electricity from the plant to the national grid of the Federal Electricity Commission (CFE) under a 15-year contract, while also selling clean energy certificates over a 20-year period.   In addition to the financing mobilized by IDB Invest, the project received a second loan of $13.9 million provided by the Spain's Institute of Official Credit (ICO) and a third loan of $8.3 million from the Bank of Tokyo (MUFG Bank Ltd).
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
[China Co-Financing Fund] IDB Invest administers $4.6 million loan from CHC for Xoxocotla Solar PV Plant

# Description
In January 2020, IDB Invest, a member of the Inter-American Development Bank Group (IDB), provided a financing package of $17.2 million in loans to X-Elio for the construction and maintenance of the Xoxocotla solar photovoltaic plant. The financing package included a 4.6 million USD loan from the China Co-Financing Fund for Latin America and the Caribbean, as well as USD 9.3 million of IDB Invest's own funds and USD 3.3 million of blended financing from the Canadian Climate Fund (C2F).  The Xoxocotla PV plant will be located in the municipality of Ayala, in the state of Morelos, and will have a 70MWAC capacity. It is hoped to displace the equivalent of 1.6 million tons of carbon dioxide over the next 20 years and is part of the Government of Mexico's goal of increasing the percentage of the country's electricity generated through clean energy.   X-Elio was awarded a long-term Power Purchase Agreement (“PPA”) for the plant by the Mexican Federal Electricity Agency, Centro Nacional de Control de Energía (“CENACE”) in September 2016. Under this agreement, X-Elio will sell electricity from the plant to the national grid of the Federal Electricity Commission (CFE) under a 15-year contract, while also selling clean energy certificates over a 20-year period.   In addition to the financing mobilized by IDB Invest, the project received a second loan of $13.9 million provided by the Spain's Institute of Official Credit (ICO) and a third loan of $8.3 million from the Bank of Tokyo (MUFG Bank Ltd).
justification: Primary purpose is solar power generation with clear renewable energy focus and carbon reduction goals
evidence: 70MWAC solar photovoltaic plant, expected to displace 1.6 million tons of CO2, part of Mexico's clean energy goals

title: Chinese Embassy provides toys to Tabasco State in Mexico
description: On December 22, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Mexico donated toys to children in Tabasco, Mexico. This donation is in response to severe flooding that took place in Tabasco. The toys will be distributed to the affected children. The specific amounts and monetary value of this donation are unknown.  An online handover ceremony took place for this donation. China’s Ambassador to Mexico, Zhu Qingqiao, the wife of the Governor of Tabasco, the Chairman of the Supervision Committee of the Public Welfare Bureau, and the Director of the State Public Welfare Bureau, Santander Lou, attended the ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Embassy provides toys to Tabasco State in Mexico

# Description
On December 22, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Mexico donated toys to children in Tabasco, Mexico. This donation is in response to severe flooding that took place in Tabasco. The toys will be distributed to the affected children. The specific amounts and monetary value of this donation are unknown.  An online handover ceremony took place for this donation. China’s Ambassador to Mexico, Zhu Qingqiao, the wife of the Governor of Tabasco, the Chairman of the Supervision Committee of the Public Welfare Bureau, and the Director of the State Public Welfare Bureau, Santander Lou, attended the ceremony.
justification: Project is a humanitarian donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Toys donated to children affected by flooding, social welfare focus

title: Chinese Government provides USD $425,000 worth of anti-epidemic supplies to the Mexican Institute of Security and Social Services of State Workers in June 2020
description: On June 25, 2020, the Chinese government donated 100,000 surgical masks, 20,000 PPE suits, 20,000 N95 masks, 20,000 infrared thermometers, 10,000 goggles, and 20,000 face shields to the Mexican Institute of Security and Social Services of State Workers (ISSSTE). This donation is valued at USD $425,000.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. China’s Ambassador to Mexico, Zhu Qingqiao, the Deputy Foreign Minister for Multilateral and Human Rights Affairs of the Mexican Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Director of the Federal Commission for the Prevention of Health Risks, the Director of the Security and Service Bureau, and Zou Chuanming, the Commercial Counselor of the Embassy, ​​attended the ceremony.  Commercial Counselor Zou Chuanming and Director Ramirez signed a material handover certificate at the ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government provides USD $425,000 worth of anti-epidemic supplies to the Mexican Institute of Security and Social Services of State Workers in June 2020

# Description
On June 25, 2020, the Chinese government donated 100,000 surgical masks, 20,000 PPE suits, 20,000 N95 masks, 20,000 infrared thermometers, 10,000 goggles, and 20,000 face shields to the Mexican Institute of Security and Social Services of State Workers (ISSSTE). This donation is valued at USD $425,000.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. China’s Ambassador to Mexico, Zhu Qingqiao, the Deputy Foreign Minister for Multilateral and Human Rights Affairs of the Mexican Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Director of the Federal Commission for the Prevention of Health Risks, the Director of the Security and Service Bureau, and Zou Chuanming, the Commercial Counselor of the Embassy, ​​attended the ceremony.  Commercial Counselor Zou Chuanming and Director Ramirez signed a material handover certificate at the ceremony.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare supplies with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of anti-epidemic supplies including masks, PPE, and medical equipment
